title: About me
text:
Bio





I am a second year part-time PhD student in Epidemiology at UGA. I have spent over five years working in sub-Saharan Africa on both HIV and malaria programs at the health facility and community levels. I now work in the Malaria Branch of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. My research interests include infectious diseases, particularly malaria, with a focus on molecular epidemiology and antimalarial resistance.


Statistical Background
I have used R in classes and for some simple statistical analyses and visuals at work, but overall, my experience is very informal, and always involves a lot of googling.) What I love about R is the level of online community engagement and discussion between people using it for such a wide variety of purposes. It can be frustrating at times, but it is by far my favorite statistical software I have worked with.
I am quite confident in study design, but the data analysis requirements for the research I do at work generally look fairly similar each time, and I have not had the confidence to explore or branch out into more complicated analyses on my own. My aim in participating in this course is to expand my R toolkit and also to gain confidence in using R more in my day to day work. I really love data visualization, so learning more about how to use Tableau with R would be another really exciting opportunity for me.


Interesting Fact
I come from a big, fat, Greek family. I have relatives named Hercules, Antigone, and Socrates to name a few!

Data Visualization: When Americans are Happiest
I have been a long time follower of various data visualization blogs, and one of my favorites is called Flowing Data. They shared a video of an interesting example of creative visualization, using data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics 2021 American Time Use Survey.
People were asked about their happiness throughout the day when they ate, traveled, watched television, took care of kids, and other activities, in addition to reporting happiness on a scale from 0 to 6, where 0 was not happy at all and 6 was very happy. The animation shows the average happiness for the fifty most common activities in individuals from age 20 to 70.

title: R Coding Exercise
text:

library("dslabs")

#overview of africadata

#fit 2000 data to a linear model (outcome = life_expectancy, predictor = population)
#no statistically significant correlation (p=0.61)

title: R Coding Exercise
section: this section added by Yao Lu
text:
this section added by Yao Lu

library('DataExplorer')
library(ggplot2)

data clean

a <- gapminder

plot_missing(a)




There 28% missing for gdp, try to narrow the continent to asia to see if that get better

asiadata <- a[which(a$continent=='Asia'),] 
plot_missing(asiadata)




Not better. Here we have 3 choice. Do imputation manually, like substitute missing GDP per capital by the mean of GDP per capital. Use ‘MICE’ package to generate a new data set with automatic imputation. Drop the rows with missing gdp.
Here for simplicity, I choose drop the missing.

asiadata1 <- asiadata[which(!is.na(asiadata$gdp)),]
plot_missing(asiadata1)



asiadata2 <- asiadata1[which(!is.na(asiadata1$infant_mortality)),]

asiadata2$gdppercap <- asiadata2$gdp/asiadata2$population

data visualization

table(droplevels(asiadata2$region))


      Central Asia       Eastern Asia South-Eastern Asia      Southern Asia 
               125                182                378                353 
      Western Asia 
               560 

hist(asiadata2$infant_mortality)



hist(asiadata2$life_expectancy)



hist(asiadata2$fertility)



hist(asiadata2$gdppercap)





p <- ggplot(data = asiadata2, aes(x = year, y = infant_mortality, group= country, color=country))
p + geom_line()+ggtitle("infant_mortality") +  xlab("year") + ylab("life time")




Here we can see all the infant_mortality decrease as the time goes on with different decreasing rate.

p <- ggplot(data = asiadata2, aes(x = year, y = life_expectancy, group= country, color=country))
p + geom_line()+ggtitle("infant_mortality") +  xlab("year") + ylab("life time")




Here we can see all the life_expectancy increase as the time goes on with different increasing rate.
data modeling

lm1 <-lm(asiadata2$life_expectancy~asiadata2$infant_mortality+asiadata2$fertility+asiadata2$region+asiadata2$gdppercap)
anova(lm1)

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: asiadata2$life_expectancy
                             Df Sum Sq Mean Sq   F value    Pr(>F)    
asiadata2$infant_mortality    1  98874   98874 14217.304 < 2.2e-16 ***
asiadata2$fertility           1    158     158    22.676 2.092e-06 ***
asiadata2$region              4   2583     646    92.857 < 2.2e-16 ***
asiadata2$gdppercap           1    837     837   120.331 < 2.2e-16 ***
Residuals                  1590  11058       7                        
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1


Here we can see that all the variables are significant. For detailed relation direction, we will see below.

summary(lm1)


Call:
lm(formula = asiadata2$life_expectancy ~ asiadata2$infant_mortality + 
    asiadata2$fertility + asiadata2$region + asiadata2$gdppercap)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-13.930  -1.458   0.048   1.419   9.407 

Coefficients:
                                     Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)                         7.660e+01  2.721e-01 281.482  < 2e-16 ***
asiadata2$infant_mortality         -1.605e-01  2.528e-03 -63.485  < 2e-16 ***
asiadata2$fertility                -5.181e-01  5.613e-02  -9.231  < 2e-16 ***
asiadata2$regionEastern Asia       -2.196e+00  3.150e-01  -6.971 4.60e-12 ***
asiadata2$regionSouth-Eastern Asia -1.355e+00  2.771e-01  -4.890 1.11e-06 ***
asiadata2$regionSouthern Asia       2.651e-01  2.813e-01   0.942    0.346    
asiadata2$regionWestern Asia        1.292e+00  2.765e-01   4.671 3.24e-06 ***
asiadata2$gdppercap                 9.079e-05  8.277e-06  10.970  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 2.637 on 1590 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.9026,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9022 
F-statistic:  2105 on 7 and 1590 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Here we know infant mortality and fertility have negative influence on life time. Gdp per capital have positive influence on life time.
The life time in different regions are not all same.

#save the output
outcome <- broom::tidy(lm1)

future work we can do
Do imputation to make use of the entire data. Find the countries who have the top life time to find what’s their similarities.
